elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Several novel manganese(II) complexes of 2,3,5,6-tetra(2-pyridyl)pyrazine have been synthesised and characterised by means of elemental analysis, IR, EPR, magnetic measurements and single crystal X-ray analysis. Two of them, [Mn(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)] and [Mn(N3)(NO3)(tppz)(H2O)], have been tested as catalysts in oxidation of alcohol to aldehydes/ketones using oxone (2KHSO5⋅KHSO4⋅K2SO4) as an oxidant under biphasic reaction conditions (CH2Cl2/H2O) and tetra-n-butylammonium bromide as phase transfer agent under air at room temperature and as catalysts in oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides with UHP (urea hydrogen peroxide) as oxidant.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A systematic studies on complex formation between Mn(II) ions, 2,3,5,6-tetra(2-pyridyl)pyrazine and halide or pseudohalide (N3 -, NCS- and N(CN)2 -) ligands have been carried out and the following complexes [Mn2(μ-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2] (1), [Mn2Cl2(μ-N3-κN1)2(tppz)2] (2), [MnCl(SCN)(tppz)(H2O)]⋅H2O (3), [MnCl(dca)(tppz)(H2O)0.57(MeOH)0.47] (4), [Mn(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)] (5), [Mn(N3)(NO3)(tppz)(H2O)] (6), [Mn(SCN)2(tppz)] (7) and [Mn(NO3)(dca)(tppz)] n  (8) have been obtained. The compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, EPR, magnetic measurements and X-ray analysis. Two of them (5 and 6) have been tested as catalysts in oxidation of alcohol to aldehydes/ketones using oxone (2KHSO5⋅KHSO4⋅K2SO4) as an oxidant under biphasic reaction conditions (CH2Cl2/H2O) and tetra-n-butylammonium bromide as phase transfer agent under air at room temperature and as catalysts in oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides with UHP (urea hydrogen peroxide) as oxidant.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

2,3,5,6-Tetra-(2-pyridyl)pyrazine (tppz), synthesized by Goodwin and Lions in 1959, was designed as an analogue of terpyridine but with the idea that it also might bridge central ions and form extended chain structures due to six potential donor sites . In metal complexes tppz forms seven distinct binding modes illustrated in  .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">As we can see from , <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> binds to a metal center in a bidentate α (a) or γ (b), bis-bidentate α (c) or γ (d), tris-bidentate (e), tridentate (f) or bis-tridentate (g) coordination mode, forming both mono- and polynuclear complexes with interesting electronic and magnetic properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As we can see from , tppz binds to a metal center in a bidentate α (a) or γ (b), bis-bidentate α (c) or γ (d), tris-bidentate (e), tridentate (f) or bis-tridentate (g) coordination mode, forming both mono- and polynuclear complexes with interesting electronic and magnetic properties.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The rich photophysical and redox properties associated with these complexes make them useful for analytical purposes and probes for biologically relevant molecules such as DNA. Recently, <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> has been examined as fluorescence sensors for series of metal ions and off–off–on switching of fluorescence depending on stepwise complex formation with <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> has been reported .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The rich photophysical and redox properties associated with these complexes make them useful for analytical purposes and probes for biologically relevant molecules such as DNA. Recently, tppz has been examined as fluorescence sensors for series of metal ions and off-off-on switching of fluorescence depending on stepwise complex formation with tppz has been reported .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Studies on <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> metal(II) complexes have illustrated the ability of this polydentate organic ligand to mediate magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers bridged by the central pyrazine moiety and hence separated by more than 6.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å . The largest antiferromagnetic interaction has been found in the dinuclear complexes [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−61.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−76<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . Interestingly, the relatively good efficiency of the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> bridge in transmitting magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers contrasts with much poorer ability of unsubstituted pyrazine bridges in its metal complexes, where negligible or weak antiferromagnetic interactions were observed (with <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> values ranging from −0.14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in [Ni(pyz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] to 15.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in Cu(pyz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ReO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) . In binuclear ruthenium(II) complexes, <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> bridges have been found to mediate intermetallic electronic communication through the π symmetry orbitals . In turn, the mononuclear complexes of Co(II) of formula [Co(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> with <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligands coordinated in a tridentate coordination mode attract scientific interest due to thermally induced spin crossover behaviour from a high-spin <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">Co</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2 at high temperatures to a low-spin <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">Co</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 at lower temperatures .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Studies on tppz metal(II) complexes have illustrated the ability of this polydentate organic ligand to mediate magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers bridged by the central pyrazine moiety and hence separated by more than 6.4Å . The largest antiferromagnetic interaction has been found in the dinuclear complexes [Cu2(tppz)(H2O)4](ClO4)4⋅2H2O (J =-61.1cm-1) and [Ni2(tppz)(H2O)6](NO3)4⋅2.5H2O (J =-76cm-1) . Interestingly, the relatively good efficiency of the tppz bridge in transmitting magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers contrasts with much poorer ability of unsubstituted pyrazine bridges in its metal complexes, where negligible or weak antiferromagnetic interactions were observed (with J values ranging from -0.14cm-1 in [Ni(pyz)2Cl2] to 15.1cm-1 in Cu(pyz)2(ReO4)2) . In binuclear ruthenium(II) complexes, tppz bridges have been found to mediate intermetallic electronic communication through the π symmetry orbitals . In turn, the mononuclear complexes of Co(II) of formula [Co(tppz)2]2+ with tppz ligands coordinated in a tridentate coordination mode attract scientific interest due to thermally induced spin crossover behaviour from a high-spin S Co =3/2 at high temperatures to a low-spin S Co =1/2 at lower temperatures .

This prompt us to systematic studies on complex formation between Mn(II) ions, <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> and halide or pseudohalide (N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and N(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) ligands. Here, we present synthesis, X-ray studies as well as spectroscopic and magnetic properties of manganese(II) complexes [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(-Cl)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">,</ce:inf> [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-κN1)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [MnCl(SCN)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [MnCl(dca)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.57</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">0.47</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), [Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), [Mn(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), [Mn(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)] (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>) and [Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(dca)(tppz)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>). The molecular structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> have been previously determined by Kwang , but the compound presented here has different conformation of the side pyridine rings and different crystal packing as compared to the literature-known one. Because the structural differences affect the magnetic properties, the contemporary structural data of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was included into study.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A search in CCDC (Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, Version 5.33) database reveals only three Mn(II) complexes of tppz, namely [Mn2(μ-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2] , [MnI(tppz)(H2O)2]I⋅H2O and [Mn(dca)(NO3)(tppz)(H2O)] . This prompt us to systematic studies on complex formation between Mn(II) ions, tppz and halide or pseudohalide (N3 -, NCS- and N(CN)2 -) ligands. Here, we present synthesis, X-ray studies as well as spectroscopic and magnetic properties of manganese(II) complexes [Mn2(-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2] (1), [Mn2Cl2(μ-N3-κN1)2(tppz)2] (2), [MnCl(SCN)(tppz)(H2O)]⋅H2O (3), [MnCl(dca)(tppz)(H2O)0.57(MeOH)0.47] (4), [Mn(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)] (5), [Mn(N3)(NO3)(tppz)(H2O)] (6), [Mn(SCN)2(tppz)] (7) and [Mn(NO3)(dca)(tppz)] n  (8). The molecular structure of 1 have been previously determined by Kwang , but the compound presented here has different conformation of the side pyridine rings and different crystal packing as compared to the literature-known one. Because the structural differences affect the magnetic properties, the contemporary structural data of 1 was included into study.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Two of these compounds (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) have been tested as catalysts in oxidation of alcohol to aldehydes/ketones using oxone (2KHSO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·KHSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) as an oxidant under biphasic reaction conditions (CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) and tetra-<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butylammonium bromide as phase transfer agent under air at room temperature and as catalysts in oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides with UHP (urea hydrogen peroxide) as oxidant. Selective oxidation of alcohols and sulfides, respectively to aldehydes/ketones and sulfoxides is a prominent reaction in laboratory and industrial synthetic chemistry . In view of their importance as intermediates in organic synthesis, several methods are available to effect this conversion, and continuous attention is drawn to newer and more selective methods of oxidation . Recently, some metal complexes with N-donor ligands were used as catalysts in these reactions .</ce:para>

<ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> and the other reagents used to the syntheses were commercially available (POCh and Aldrich) and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 560 spectrometer in the spectral range 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> with the samples in the form of KBr pellets.</ce:para>

Experimental

 tppz and the other reagents used to the syntheses were commercially available (POCh and Aldrich) and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 560 spectrometer in the spectral range 4000-400cm-1 with the samples in the form of KBr pellets.

<ce:section-title>Preparation of [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-Cl)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">
<ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> was dissolved in a mixture of methanol/acetonitrile (30/60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) and slowly added to methanolic solution of MnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O or Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, and stirred at room temperature for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The resulting solution was allowed to evaporate at room temperature and crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> were obtained after several days.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Mn2(μ-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2] (1) and [Mn(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)] (5)

 tppz was dissolved in a mixture of methanol/acetonitrile (30/60ml) and slowly added to methanolic solution of MnCl2⋅4H2O or Mn(NO3)⋅4H2O, and stirred at room temperature for 12h. The resulting solution was allowed to evaporate at room temperature and crystals of 1 and 5 were obtained after several days.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature. Details concerning crystal data and refinement are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Lorentz, polarization and empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics implemented in <ce:small-caps>scale</ce:small-caps>3 <ce:small-caps>abspack</ce:small-caps> scaling algorithm  were applied. The structures were solved by the direct methods and subsequently completed by the difference Fourier recycling. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using full-matrix, least-squares technique. The hydrogen atoms were treated as “riding” on their parent carbon atoms and assigned isotropic temperature factors equal 1.2 (aromatic) and 1.5 (water) times the value of equivalent temperature factor of the parent atom. The methyl groups were allowed to rotate about their local threefold axis. <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>97 and <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>97  programs were used for all the calculations. Atomic scattering factors were those incorporated in the computer programs. At <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, ½, ½ the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> have the solvent accessible void of about 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, filled with the continuous electron density not larger than 0.377<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>e<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>. Because such density do not show any clear maximum it can be stated that above mentioned solvent accessible void is filled with the diffused solvent (multiple, differently disordered solvent molecules). Refinement of the model which does not comprise the diffused solvent leads to the satisfactory and reasonable structural parameters (). The compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> contains build up into the inner coordination sphere the disorder solvent molecules (water/methanol). These solvents exist almost alternately in the crystal net molecules and the oxygen atoms of both molecules occupy almost equivalent places in the asymmetric unit.</ce:para>

(2) [Mn2Cl2(μ-N3-kN1)2(tppz)2]

(6) [Mn(N3)(NO3)(tppz)(H2O)]

(7) [Mn(SCN)2(tppz)]

The compound was prepared by employing NH4SCN (0.10g 1.6mmol), Mn(NO3)⋅4H2O (0.2g 0.8mmol) and tppz (0.31g, 0.8mmol). Yield 75% (334mg).

Calc. for C26H16MnN8S2: C, 55.81; H, 2.88; N, 20.03. Found: C, 55.21; H, 3.01; N, 20.69%.

IR (KBr, cm-1): 2310 ν s(CN) and 2172 ν as + ν s(CN) 1590 (s), 1568 (sh) and 1537 (w) ν(CN) and ν(CC).

Crystal structures determination and refinement

The X-ray intensity data of 1-8 were collected on a Gemini A Ultra diffractometer equipped with Atlas CCD detector and graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature. Details concerning crystal data and refinement are given in  . Lorentz, polarization and empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics implemented in scale3 abspack scaling algorithm  were applied. The structures were solved by the direct methods and subsequently completed by the difference Fourier recycling. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using full-matrix, least-squares technique. The hydrogen atoms were treated as "riding" on their parent carbon atoms and assigned isotropic temperature factors equal 1.2 (aromatic) and 1.5 (water) times the value of equivalent temperature factor of the parent atom. The methyl groups were allowed to rotate about their local threefold axis. shelxs97 and shelxl97  programs were used for all the calculations. Atomic scattering factors were those incorporated in the computer programs. At x, ½, ½ the compound 1 have the solvent accessible void of about 180Å3, filled with the continuous electron density not larger than 0.377eÅ-3. Because such density do not show any clear maximum it can be stated that above mentioned solvent accessible void is filled with the diffused solvent (multiple, differently disordered solvent molecules). Refinement of the model which does not comprise the diffused solvent leads to the satisfactory and reasonable structural parameters (). The compound 4 contains build up into the inner coordination sphere the disorder solvent molecules (water/methanol). These solvents exist almost alternately in the crystal net molecules and the oxygen atoms of both molecules occupy almost equivalent places in the asymmetric unit.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic measurement and EPR spectra

Variable-temperature magnetic measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMSXL-5-type) at a magnetic field of 0.5T over the temperature range 1.8-300K. Correction are based on subtracting the sample-holder signal, contribution χ Dia estimated from Pascal constants . The effective magnetic moment was calculated from the equation:     μ   eff   = 2.83 (   χ   M   T   )   1 / 2     (B.M.). Magnetization versus magnetic field measurements were carried out at 2K in the magnetic field range 0-5T.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Catalytic studies</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General procedure in oxidation of alcohol</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0185" view="all">In a typical experiment, a solution of Oxone (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) at room temperature was added to a solution of alcohol (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), tetra-<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butylammonium bromide, (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and catalyst (0.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and the biphasic mixture stirred vigorously. Formation of products and consumption of substrates were monitored by gas chromatography. The identity of products was determined by comparison with authentic samples using gas–liquid chromatography. Oxidation products yields based on the oxidant, were quantified by comparison with chlorobenzene.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic studies

General procedure in oxidation of alcohol

In a typical experiment, a solution of Oxone (0.2mmol) in H2O (5ml) at room temperature was added to a solution of alcohol (0.2mmol), tetra-n-butylammonium bromide, (0.1mmol), and catalyst (0.01mmol), in CH2Cl2 (1mL), and the biphasic mixture stirred vigorously. Formation of products and consumption of substrates were monitored by gas chromatography. The identity of products was determined by comparison with authentic samples using gas-liquid chromatography. Oxidation products yields based on the oxidant, were quantified by comparison with chlorobenzene.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>General procedure for sulfide oxidation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0190" view="all">To a solution of sulfide (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), imidazole (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) as axial ligand, chlorobenzene (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) as internal standard and catalyst (0.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a (1:1) mixture of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was added UHP (0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) as oxidant. The mixture was stirred at room temperature and the progress of the reaction was monitored by GC, by removing small samples of the reaction mixture. To establish the identity of the products unequivocally, the retention times and spectral data were compared to those of commercially available compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
General procedure for sulfide oxidation

To a solution of sulfide (0.2mmol), imidazole (0.1mmol) as axial ligand, chlorobenzene (0.2mmol) as internal standard and catalyst (0.01mmol) in a (1:1) mixture of CH3OH/CH2Cl2 (1ml) was added UHP (0.4mmol) as oxidant. The mixture was stirred at room temperature and the progress of the reaction was monitored by GC, by removing small samples of the reaction mixture. To establish the identity of the products unequivocally, the retention times and spectral data were compared to those of commercially available compounds.

The reaction of <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> with MnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> yields [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-Cl)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), while Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> reacts with <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> to form [Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>). Interestingly, the choice of manganese(II) salt turned out to be crucial in complex formation with <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> and pseudohalide ligands. MnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> reacts with <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> and NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>SCN, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or NaN(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to give [MnCl(SCN)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-kN1)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [MnCl(dca)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.57</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">0.47</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), respectively, whereas the reactions of Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> and NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>SCN, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or NaN(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> yield [Mn(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)] (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), [Mn(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) and [Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(dca)(tppz)]<ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Preparation and infrared data

The preparations of complexes 1-8 were carried out in a mixture methanol-acetonitrile in molar ratio of manganese(II) ions to ligand equal 1:1, and two manganese(II) salts (MnCl2 4H2O and Mn(NO3)2 4H2O) were used for the syntheses. The reaction of tppz with MnCl2 yields [Mn2(μ-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2] (1), while Mn(NO3)2 reacts with tppz to form [Mn(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)] (5). Interestingly, the choice of manganese(II) salt turned out to be crucial in complex formation with tppz and pseudohalide ligands. MnCl2 reacts with tppz and NH4SCN, NaN3 or NaN(CN)2 to give [MnCl(SCN)(tppz)(H2O)]⋅H2O (3), [Mn2Cl2(μ-N3-kN1)2(tppz)2] (2) and [MnCl(dca)(tppz)(H2O)0.57(MeOH)0.47] (4), respectively, whereas the reactions of Mn(NO3)2 with tppz and NH4SCN, NaN3 or NaN(CN)2 yield [Mn(SCN)2(tppz)] (7), [Mn(N3)(NO3)(tppz)(H2O)] (6) and [Mn(NO3)(dca)(tppz)] n  (8).

Intense absorptions associated with the stretching modes of the pseudohalide ions occur at 2065<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 2063<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 2299, 2228 and 2176<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, 2061<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, 2048<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, 2310 and 2172<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>. Peaks revealing the presence of <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> occur in the ranges 3100–2880<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (aromatic C–H stretching vibrations), 1600–1530<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C) stretches), 1480–1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>C–C)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

In the case of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> the region 1480–1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is partially obscured by the strong nitrate NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text: In high frequency region the IR spectra of 3, 4, 5 and 6 show broad and strong absorptions centered at 3391cm-1 for 3, 3395, 3324 and 3209cm-1 for 4, 3415cm-1 for 5 and 3394cm-1 for 6, assignable to the O-H stretching water molecules. Intense absorptions associated with the stretching modes of the pseudohalide ions occur at 2065cm-1 for 2, 2063cm-1 for 3, 2299, 2228 and 2176cm-1 for 4, 2061cm-1 for 6, 2048cm-1 for 7, 2310 and 2172cm-1 for 8. Peaks revealing the presence of tppz occur in the ranges 3100-2880cm-1 (aromatic C-H stretching vibrations), 1600-1530cm-1 (ν(CN) and ν(CC) stretches), 1480-1000cm-1 (νC-C)+ ν(C-N) vibrations) and 800-700cm-1 (aromatic C-H deformation vibrations). In the case of 5, 6 and 8 the region 1480-1000cm-1 is partially obscured by the strong nitrate NO3 - stretching modes .

The compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not show any interaction which can be classified even as weak hydrogen bond, however, due to existence of diffused solvent in the crystal structure, the intermolecular contacts scheme is incomplete and some bonding interactions between the solvent and complex molecules eventually may exist. It can be postulated that formation of the hydrogen bond between the solvent and complex molecules leads to stabilization of the solvent molecules positions in the crystal structure, thus the presence of diffused solvent may indicated a lack of the intermolecular interactions between the solvent and complex molecules. elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure analysis

The crystallographic data of 1-8 are summarized in .

The intra- and intermolecular contacts  detected in the structures 2-8 are collected in . The compound 1 does not show any interaction which can be classified even as weak hydrogen bond, however, due to existence of diffused solvent in the crystal structure, the intermolecular contacts scheme is incomplete and some bonding interactions between the solvent and complex molecules eventually may exist. It can be postulated that formation of the hydrogen bond between the solvent and complex molecules leads to stabilization of the solvent molecules positions in the crystal structure, thus the presence of diffused solvent may indicated a lack of the intermolecular interactions between the solvent and complex molecules. The molecules of compounds 2, 7 and 8 are interconnected only by weak C-H⋯D hydrogen bonds (), respectively, to the chains extending along the crystallographic [011] axis, to the dimers and to the ribbons exiting along the crystallographic [010] axis and perpendicular to the crystallographic (01     3   ¯    ) plane. The complex molecules of 3 are connected by O-H⋯Cl medium strength hydrogen bonds to the chains extending along crystallographic [010] axis and described C(4) graph. The unitary graph set is formed by these C(4) motifs and additional D motifs of O-H⋯O hydrogen bonds. The weak C-H⋯Cl hydrogen bonds () expands above mentioned chins to the layers propagating along crystallographic (10     1   ¯    ) plane, and weak C-H⋯S hydrogen bonds () extents these layers to the 3D supramolecular network. The molecules of 4 are linked to hydrogen bonded dimers by O-H⋯N interactions forming N1C2 2(16) motifs. The presence of the weak C-H⋯Cl hydrogen bonds lead to formation of the 3D network in 4. The medium strength O-H⋯A hydrogen bonds link the molecules of 5 to the chains extending along crystallographic [010] axis and described by C(4)C(6)C(8) basic unitary graph set motifs. The weak C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds expands these chains to the 3D supramolecular network. In compound 6, similarly to the 5, the O-H⋯N hydrogen bonds extents molecules to the chains located along crystallographic [010] axis but they forms the C(4)C(5)C(8) basic unitary graph set. Additionally the weak C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds present in 6 link above mentioned chain to the plane expanding along the crystallographic (001) plane. Additionally the molecules of the compounds 2-6 and 8 are internally liked by the by the weak C-H⋯A intramolecular bonds.

elements.clean_text:
[Mn2(-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2] (1) and [Mn2Cl2(-N3-N1)2(tppz)2] (2)

Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize in the triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . Perspective view of the molecule 2 with the labeling of the atoms are depicted in  , and the relevant bond lengths of 1 and 2 are collected in  . The molecular structure of 1 and detailed structural parameters of 1 and 2 were included in ). The dinuclear complexes 1 and 2 result from the pairing of two mononuclear units related by a crystallographic center of inversion. In 1 the manganese(II) centers are doubly bridged by chloride ions, whereas the Mn(II) of 2 are doubly linked by end-on (EO) azide groups.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0220" view="all">In both dimers, the four atoms involved in bridging form a perfect plane due to the existence of an inversion center. The resulting intradinuclear Mn⋯Mn separation of 3.859<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 3.553<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> falls in the range reported for the related Mn(II) dimers . Similarly, the bridging angles Mn(1)–Cl(2)–Mn(1)#1 (96.59(3)°) and Mn(1)–N(99)–Mn(1)#1 (104.91(11)°) are in good agreement with data reported in the literature, for example in [MnCl(μ-Cl)(mpbpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> the Mn(1)–Cl(1)–Mn(1)<ce:sup loc="post">i</ce:sup> angle equals 94.426(19)°  and in [Mn(terpy)(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] 2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O the Mn– N4–Mn<ce:sup loc="post">i</ce:sup> angle is 104.6(1)°) . The two Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl bridging bond lengths in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are significantly different (2.4227(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 2.7391<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). A similar trend is observed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, where Mn–N corresponding to the bridging azide groups are equal 2.161(2) and 2.319(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In both dimers, the four atoms involved in bridging form a perfect plane due to the existence of an inversion center. The resulting intradinuclear Mn⋯Mn separation of 3.859Å in 1 and 3.553Å in 2 falls in the range reported for the related Mn(II) dimers . Similarly, the bridging angles Mn(1)-Cl(2)-Mn(1)#1 (96.59(3)°) and Mn(1)-N(99)-Mn(1)#1 (104.91(11)°) are in good agreement with data reported in the literature, for example in [MnCl(μ-Cl)(mpbpa)]2 the Mn(1)-Cl(1)-Mn(1)i angle equals 94.426(19)°  and in [Mn(terpy)(N3)2] 2H2O the Mn- N4-Mni angle is 104.6(1)°) . The two Mn2Cl bridging bond lengths in 1 are significantly different (2.4227(10)Å and 2.7391Å). A similar trend is observed in 2, where Mn-N corresponding to the bridging azide groups are equal 2.161(2) and 2.319(3)Å.

In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the Mn(1) ions are coordinated by three N atoms from the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand and three chloride ligands giving a six-coordinate <ce:italic>mer</ce:italic>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> donor set. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> three nitrogen atoms of the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand and one nitrogen atom of end-on azido ligand act as the equatorial plane, while the nitrogen atom of the second <ce:italic>end-on</ce:italic> azido ligand and chloride ion situate in the axial positions.</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0230" view="all">The Mn–N bond lengths, ranging from 2.243(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å to 2.319(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and Mn–Cl distances, from 2.4227(10) to 2.7391(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, fall within the normal range in dimers incorporating six-coordinate manganese(II) ions . In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the bond distance of Mn(II) to the middle nitrogen N(1) is shorter than Mn(1)–N(3) and Mn(1)–N(4) distances, which is usually observed in <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic>-like ligands . The shortness of Mn–N<ce:inf loc="post">pyrazine</ce:inf> distance within the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> unit is attributed to a more efficient overlap of the metal t<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> orbitals with the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> orbitals of the central pyrazine ring compared to the distal pyridyl groups. This trend is not observed in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, probably due to a <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> effect of the azide group.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Mn-N bond lengths, ranging from 2.243(3)Å to 2.319(3)Å, and Mn-Cl distances, from 2.4227(10) to 2.7391(10)Å, fall within the normal range in dimers incorporating six-coordinate manganese(II) ions . In 1, the bond distance of Mn(II) to the middle nitrogen N(1) is shorter than Mn(1)-N(3) and Mn(1)-N(4) distances, which is usually observed in tppz-like ligands . The shortness of Mn-Npyrazine distance within the tppz unit is attributed to a more efficient overlap of the metal t2g orbitals with the π∗ orbitals of the central pyrazine ring compared to the distal pyridyl groups. This trend is not observed in complex 2, probably due to a trans effect of the azide group.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0235" view="all">The <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand is appreciably twisted, dihedral angles between the pyrazine ring and each of the pyridyl rings are equal 41.35(12)°, 31.95(14)°, 30.03(15)° and 21.74(16) ° in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 51.85(10)°, 29.53(12)°, 26.77(15)° and 18.57(17)° in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The pyrazine ring itself is puckered with maximum atomic deviations from a best mean plane being 0.1053<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at C(4) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 0.0995<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at C(2) in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The torsion angles N1–C1–C2–N2 and N2–C3–C4–N1 are −18.51(41)° and 16.83(39)° in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and, and the dihedral angle between the two C–N–C planes of the pyrazine ring is 10.07(46)° in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 5.18(33)° in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The non-planarity of the pyrazine ring is unexceptional. It has been reported for the related structures , and the factor responsible for destabilizing the planar geometry of the pyrazine ring has a pure electronic origin .</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:section-title>[Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and [Mn(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0255" view="all">The manganese(II) ions of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are heptacoordinated with coordination polyhedron close to the pentagonal bipyramid (). In <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> the heptacoordination is achieved by means of three N atoms from the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand and two oxygen atoms from the bidentate nitrate ligand, which determine the equatorial plane, and two oxygen atoms, from the water molecule and monodentate nitrate group, in axial positions. The equatorial plane of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> is also constituted by three N atoms of <ce:italic>tpzz</ce:italic> ligand and two oxygen atoms from the bidentate nitrate ligand, but axial positions are occupied by the oxygen atom belonging to the water molecule and nitrogen atom of the azide group. A rare heptacoordinated geometry of Mn(II) ions in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> seems to be govern by simultaneous existence of bidentate nitrate ligand leading to the formation of four-membered chelate ring and tridentate <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand forming with the central ion two five-membered chelate rings. The deviation from ideal pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, clearly indicated by bond angles in the equatorial plane, comes from the bites taken by the nitrate ion (54.19(8) in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and 54.01(8) in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) and <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligands (70.41(9) and 70.45(9) in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and 69.75(9) and 70.95(9) in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>). In turn, the bond angles N(3)–Mn(1)–O(1) (81.60(11)°) and N(4)–Mn(1)–O(2) (85.04(11)°) are considerably greater than ideal for pentagonal bipyramidal geometry value 72°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Mn(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)] (5) and [Mn(N3)(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)] (6)

The manganese(II) ions of 5 and 6 are heptacoordinated with coordination polyhedron close to the pentagonal bipyramid (). In 5 the heptacoordination is achieved by means of three N atoms from the tppz ligand and two oxygen atoms from the bidentate nitrate ligand, which determine the equatorial plane, and two oxygen atoms, from the water molecule and monodentate nitrate group, in axial positions. The equatorial plane of 6 is also constituted by three N atoms of tpzz ligand and two oxygen atoms from the bidentate nitrate ligand, but axial positions are occupied by the oxygen atom belonging to the water molecule and nitrogen atom of the azide group. A rare heptacoordinated geometry of Mn(II) ions in 5 and 6 seems to be govern by simultaneous existence of bidentate nitrate ligand leading to the formation of four-membered chelate ring and tridentate tppz ligand forming with the central ion two five-membered chelate rings. The deviation from ideal pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, clearly indicated by bond angles in the equatorial plane, comes from the bites taken by the nitrate ion (54.19(8) in 5 and 54.01(8) in 6) and tppz ligands (70.41(9) and 70.45(9) in 5 and 69.75(9) and 70.95(9) in 6). In turn, the bond angles N(3)-Mn(1)-O(1) (81.60(11)°) and N(4)-Mn(1)-O(2) (85.04(11)°) are considerably greater than ideal for pentagonal bipyramidal geometry value 72°.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0260" view="all">The individual pyridyl rings are planar within experimental errors, while the pyrazine ring is significantly puckered, with maximum atomic deviations from a best mean plane being 0.1105(20)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at C(2) in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and 0.1112(21)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at C(2) in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>). The dihedral angles between the pyrazine and uncoordinated pyridyl rings are 38.86(13)° and 34.50(14)° in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and 38.60(16)° and 36.06(17)° in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, whereas the coordinated pyridine rings are inclined toward the pyrazine ring by 20.16(10) and 25.86(9) in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and 18.86(11) and 26.74(10) in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. The Mn–N bonds involving the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand vary from 2.267(2) to 2.327(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Mn–N distance for the coordinated pyrazine is slightly shorter in comparison with Mn–N<ce:inf loc="post">pyridine</ce:inf> ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The individual pyridyl rings are planar within experimental errors, while the pyrazine ring is significantly puckered, with maximum atomic deviations from a best mean plane being 0.1105(20)Å at C(2) in 5 and 0.1112(21)Å at C(2) in 6). The dihedral angles between the pyrazine and uncoordinated pyridyl rings are 38.86(13)° and 34.50(14)° in 5 and 38.60(16)° and 36.06(17)° in 6, whereas the coordinated pyridine rings are inclined toward the pyrazine ring by 20.16(10) and 25.86(9) in 5 and 18.86(11) and 26.74(10) in 6. The Mn-N bonds involving the tppz ligand vary from 2.267(2) to 2.327(3)Å, and the Mn-N distance for the coordinated pyrazine is slightly shorter in comparison with Mn-Npyridine ().

elements.content: <ce:section-title>[Mn(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)] (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0270" view="all">The molecular structure of <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> with the labeling of the atoms is depicted in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are collected in . The manganese(II) ion is five-coordinate by three N atoms of <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand and two atoms of thiocyanate ions and shows square-based pyramidal geometry (SP). The equatorial plane of manganese(II), defined by three <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> nitrogen atoms and one nitrogen atom of the thiocyanate group, has a slight tetrahedral distortion and the metal atom is displaced by 0.317(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from this plane in the direction of the apical position, occupying by the nitrogen atom of the second SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion. As in the aforementioned structures, the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand is appreciably twisted, the coordinated pyridine rings are inclined toward the central pyrazine by 24.89(8)° and 29.83(7)°, and dihedral angles between the pyrazine and uncoordinated pyridyl rings are 46.58(7)° and 56.78(5)°. Interestingly, the pyrazine ring in <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> is flat within experimental error (maximum atomic deviation at C(2) equals to 0.0221(14)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Mn(SCN)2(tppz)] (7)

The molecular structure of 7 with the labeling of the atoms is depicted in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are collected in . The manganese(II) ion is five-coordinate by three N atoms of tppz ligand and two atoms of thiocyanate ions and shows square-based pyramidal geometry (SP). The equatorial plane of manganese(II), defined by three tppz nitrogen atoms and one nitrogen atom of the thiocyanate group, has a slight tetrahedral distortion and the metal atom is displaced by 0.317(1)Å from this plane in the direction of the apical position, occupying by the nitrogen atom of the second SCN- ion. As in the aforementioned structures, the tppz ligand is appreciably twisted, the coordinated pyridine rings are inclined toward the central pyrazine by 24.89(8)° and 29.83(7)°, and dihedral angles between the pyrazine and uncoordinated pyridyl rings are 46.58(7)° and 56.78(5)°. Interestingly, the pyrazine ring in 7 is flat within experimental error (maximum atomic deviation at C(2) equals to 0.0221(14)Å).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0275" view="all">The Mn–N, ranging from 2.032(2) to 2.4555(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, are consistent with the values observed in other penta-coordinated mononuclear manganese(II) complexes . The Mn–N bond length is shortest for thiocyanate nitrogens, indicating their stronger coordination than the pyridyl and pyrazine nitrogens of tppz ligand. Similar to the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the bond distance of Mn(II) to the middle nitrogen N(1) is slightly longer than Mn(1)–N(3) and Mn(1)–N(4) distances, which is probably due to a <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> effect of the thiocyanate group. The NCS groups are quasilinear with N–C–S bond angle of 178.7(3)° and 179.5(2)° and are bonded to the metal ion through an angle of 165.5(2)° and 137.2(2)°, respectively. The bent coordination is rarer compared to the linear one. Previously, it was reported for [Mn(dpka)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·½H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (∠Mn–N–C: 157.95(11)° and 139.20(9)°) , [Cu(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (∠Cu–N–C: 127.49(10)°)  and [Cu(bedmpza)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (∠Cu–N–C: 140.75(10)° and 173.44(11)°) .</ce:para>

The intrachain Mn⋯Mn separation of 8.784<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å falls in the range reported for the Mn(II) coordination polymers based on μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,5</ce:inf>–N(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bridges, e.g. {[Mn(azpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(dca)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]-(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(azpy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (8.425<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)  Mn[N(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2,5-me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pyz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (8.425<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . Each manganese center is seven-coordinated by three N atoms from the <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand, two oxygen atoms of the nitrate ligand and two nitrogen atoms belonging to μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,5</ce:inf>-bridged <ce:italic>dca</ce:italic>. The coordination polyhedron of Mn(II) ions is best described as pentagonal bipyramid with the equatorial plane being defined by nitrogen atoms of <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> and nitrate oxygen donors. Similarly to the mononuclear complexes (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), the nitrate group coordinates in a symmetric bidentate mode to the central ion (). The <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand is significantly twisted. The pyrazine ring is puckered with maximum atomic deviations from a best mean plane being 0.0644(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at C(4), and the dihedral angles between the pyrazine ring and each of the pyridyl rings are equal 27.00(9)°, 25.83(10)°, 44.64(11)° and 73.76(6)°. The coordination bond lengths and angles, reported in , are not unexceptional and correlate well with the values discussed for structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and given for the related complexes [Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(dca)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] , [Mn(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)(dca)(tppz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
 and [Mn(dca)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(terpy)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The dicyanamide ligand is angular with a C(99)-N(97)-C(98) angle of 126.8(3)° and two nearly linear N-C-N units with angle of 170.3(3)°. The intrachain Mn⋯Mn separation of 8.784Å falls in the range reported for the Mn(II) coordination polymers based on μ1,5-N(CN)2 bridges, e.g. {[Mn(azpy)2(dca)(H2O)2]-(ClO4)(azpy)(H2O)2} n  (8.425Å)  Mn[N(CN)2]2(H2O)2(2,5-me2pyz)2] (8.425Å) . Each manganese center is seven-coordinated by three N atoms from the tppz ligand, two oxygen atoms of the nitrate ligand and two nitrogen atoms belonging to μ1,5-bridged dca. The coordination polyhedron of Mn(II) ions is best described as pentagonal bipyramid with the equatorial plane being defined by nitrogen atoms of tppz and nitrate oxygen donors. Similarly to the mononuclear complexes (5 and 6), the nitrate group coordinates in a symmetric bidentate mode to the central ion (). The tppz ligand is significantly twisted. The pyrazine ring is puckered with maximum atomic deviations from a best mean plane being 0.0644(15)Å at C(4), and the dihedral angles between the pyrazine ring and each of the pyridyl rings are equal 27.00(9)°, 25.83(10)°, 44.64(11)° and 73.76(6)°. The coordination bond lengths and angles, reported in , are not unexceptional and correlate well with the values discussed for structures 1-7 and given for the related complexes [Mn(NO3)(dca)(tppz)(H2O)] , [Mn(CH3COO)(dca)(tppz)(H2O)]⋅(H2O)2  and [Mn(dca)(NO3)(terpy)] n  .

elements.clean_text:
Continuous shape measures (CShM)

The distortion of the coordination sphere of the Mn(II) ions in 1-8 from ideal polyhedra has been calculated using the shape program  based on continuous shape measures (CShM) concept. CShM allows to determine a distance between the real metal environment and ideal polyhedron. Mathematically CShM of the original structure (Q) is a normalized root-mean-square deviation from the referenced structure with the desired symmetry (P) and it is expressed by Eq. :  (1)    S   Q   ( P ) =  min         ∑   i = 1   n   |     q   →     i   -     p   →     i     |   2       ∑   i = 1   n   |     q   →     i   -     q   →     0     |   2        × 100   where,       q   →     i     are N vectors that contain the 3N Cartesian coordinates of the problem structure Q, and       p   →     i     contain the coordinates of the ideal polyhedron P and       q   →     i     is the position vector of the geometric center that is chosen to be the same for the two polyhedra . The minimum is taken for all possible relative orientations in space, isotropic scaling, and for all possible pairings of the vertexes of the problem and reference polyhedra. The value SQ (P) tends to zero, when considered polyhedron Q is close to ideal one . The maximum allowed value SQ (P) is 100, although in practice the values found for severely distorted chemical structures are very rarely larger than 40.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0295" view="all">The results of shape measurements for Mn(II) ions in the examined structures are summarized in .</ce:para><ce:para id="p0300" view="all">Metal centers of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> present a six-coordinated environment and their geometries were referred to two ideal polyhedra: octahedron (O<ce:inf loc="post">h</ce:inf>) and trigonal prism (TPR). The most characteristic distortion of these systems is the Bailar trigonal twist, which leading from perfect octahedron to perfect trigonal prism and results from rotating by 60° two opposite faces of the octahedron around their C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> axis . In case when only two ideal polyhedra are taken into consideration (as for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> octahedron and trigonal prism), each distortion can be represented by specific scatterplot in two-dimensional space defined by the two symmetry measures <ce:italic>S<ce:inf loc="post">Q</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(O<ce:inf loc="post">h</ce:inf>) and <ce:italic>S<ce:inf loc="post">Q</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(TRP). This scatterplot is called a shape map .  shows the octahedron–trigonal pathway and includes the calculated shape measures for coordination sphere of the experimental structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. For all compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>(O<ce:inf loc="post">h</ce:inf>) is lower than value 4.42 corresponding to the intermediate geometry (with <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>30°) being isosymmetric with respect to the octahedron and the trigonal prism. Therefore, the structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are closer to an octahedron than to a trigonal prism and can be best described as a distorted octahedron. Dimers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are more distorted in comparison with mononuclear complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and azide bridges cause a larger distortion than chloride ions. In turn, analysis of Fig. 9 reveals that calculated shape measures for coordination sphere of the structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> do not appear along the Bailar path. Such deviation is typical for six-coordinated complexes incorporating polydentate ligands with small bite angles.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The results of shape measurements for Mn(II) ions in the examined structures are summarized in .

Metal centers of compounds 1-4 present a six-coordinated environment and their geometries were referred to two ideal polyhedra: octahedron (Oh) and trigonal prism (TPR). The most characteristic distortion of these systems is the Bailar trigonal twist, which leading from perfect octahedron to perfect trigonal prism and results from rotating by 60° two opposite faces of the octahedron around their C3 axis . In case when only two ideal polyhedra are taken into consideration (as for 1-4 octahedron and trigonal prism), each distortion can be represented by specific scatterplot in two-dimensional space defined by the two symmetry measures SQ (Oh) and SQ (TRP). This scatterplot is called a shape map .  shows the octahedron-trigonal pathway and includes the calculated shape measures for coordination sphere of the experimental structures 1-4. For all compounds 1-4, S(Oh) is lower than value 4.42 corresponding to the intermediate geometry (with θ =30°) being isosymmetric with respect to the octahedron and the trigonal prism. Therefore, the structures 1-4 are closer to an octahedron than to a trigonal prism and can be best described as a distorted octahedron. Dimers 1 and 2 are more distorted in comparison with mononuclear complexes 3 and 4, and azide bridges cause a larger distortion than chloride ions. In turn, analysis of Fig. 9 reveals that calculated shape measures for coordination sphere of the structures 1-4 do not appear along the Bailar path. Such deviation is typical for six-coordinated complexes incorporating polydentate ligands with small bite angles.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0305" view="all">Manganese(II) ions of the complexes <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> are seven-coordinated and their geometries were referred to three commonly seven-vertexes polyhedra: pentagonal bipyramid (PBPY), capped octahedron (COC) and capped trigonal prism (CTP). The CShM of manganese(II) ions in compounds <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> revealed that their geometry is closer to pentagonal bipyramid (PBPY) than to the other seven-vertexes polyhedron (). The distances to the capped octahedron (COC) and capped trigonal prism (CTP) are much larger than to the PBPY. Generally, it is assumed that shape measures of less than 1.0 indicate minor distortions from the reference shape values of up to 3.0 units indicate important distortions, but the reference shape provides still a good stereochemical description.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Manganese(II) ions of the complexes 5, 6 and 8 are seven-coordinated and their geometries were referred to three commonly seven-vertexes polyhedra: pentagonal bipyramid (PBPY), capped octahedron (COC) and capped trigonal prism (CTP). The CShM of manganese(II) ions in compounds 5, 6 and 7 revealed that their geometry is closer to pentagonal bipyramid (PBPY) than to the other seven-vertexes polyhedron (). The distances to the capped octahedron (COC) and capped trigonal prism (CTP) are much larger than to the PBPY. Generally, it is assumed that shape measures of less than 1.0 indicate minor distortions from the reference shape values of up to 3.0 units indicate important distortions, but the reference shape provides still a good stereochemical description.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0310" view="all">Two ideal shapes, the trigonal bipyramid (TBP) of <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3h</ce:inf> symmetry, and the square pyramid (SPY) of <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4v</ce:inf> symmetry, were taken into account in continuous shape measures for geometry of the penta-coordinated metal center in <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>. The CShM values () indicate the predominance of square-based pyramidal (SP) geometry of the manganese(II) ion in structure <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and well correlate with the value of angular parameter <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.36 also describing the structure <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> as a distorted square pyramid .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Two ideal shapes, the trigonal bipyramid (TBP) of D 3h symmetry, and the square pyramid (SPY) of C 4v symmetry, were taken into account in continuous shape measures for geometry of the penta-coordinated metal center in 7. The CShM values () indicate the predominance of square-based pyramidal (SP) geometry of the manganese(II) ion in structure 7 and well correlate with the value of angular parameter τ =0.36 also describing the structure 7 as a distorted square pyramid .

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties and EPR spectra

The values χMT of monometallic complexes in the temperature range 10-300K are near constant. The slight decrease of the value χMT at the lowest temperatures range (1.8-10K) is caused by occurrence of a very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) centers in the crystal lattice. All magnetic data are presented in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0320" view="all">The variation of the magnetization <ce:italic>M</ce:italic> versus the magnetic field <ce:italic>H</ce:italic> have been measured for all complexes at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K indicates linear relation to ∼1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T and than continues Brillouin function. All these data confirms presence of spin <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>/<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and a small lowering values of magnetic moment of manganese(II) centers. The EPR parameters of powdered spectra of all compounds are presented in the .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The variation of the magnetization M versus the magnetic field H have been measured for all complexes at 2K indicates linear relation to ~1T and than continues Brillouin function. All these data confirms presence of spin S = 5/2 and a small lowering values of magnetic moment of manganese(II) centers. The EPR parameters of powdered spectra of all compounds are presented in the .

The least-squares fit of the experimental data using these equations were limited to the temperature range from 1.8K up to 300K ( ).

The magnetic data of 1D chain complex indicated weak antiferromagnetic properties and have been fit using Fisher's classical Heisenberg results  for infinite linear chains.

The molecular field approximation has been used to account for interaction between chains. <ce:section-title>Catalytic experiments</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0380" view="all">In order to compare catalytic reactivity of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> with other compounds, we used the same optimization condition with our previous work . Reactions were performed at room temperature under air in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O containing the manganese complex, tetra-<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butylammonium bromide, substrate and Oxone in 1:20:10:20 molar ratio, respectively. The system was applicable for the oxidation of a wide variety of primary benzylic alcohols to corresponding aldehydes (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0025"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic experiments

In order to compare catalytic reactivity of 5 and 6 with other compounds, we used the same optimization condition with our previous work . Reactions were performed at room temperature under air in CH2Cl2/H2O containing the manganese complex, tetra-n-butylammonium bromide, substrate and Oxone in 1:20:10:20 molar ratio, respectively. The system was applicable for the oxidation of a wide variety of primary benzylic alcohols to corresponding aldehydes ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0385" view="all">Benzylalcohols were oxidized to give the corresponding aldehydes with 91–100% conversion (entries 1–8). The substrates having electron-donating and -withdrawing substituents in the aromatic ring were compatible with this protocol. The change of nature and site of substituents (methyl, methoxy, chloro and nitro) in the aromatic ring of benzylalcohol to probe electronic effects displayed no regular trends in the conversion. The catalytic oxidation of alcohols in the given conditions showed excellent efficiency in terms of yield and selectivity (100%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Benzylalcohols were oxidized to give the corresponding aldehydes with 91-100% conversion (entries 1-8). The substrates having electron-donating and -withdrawing substituents in the aromatic ring were compatible with this protocol. The change of nature and site of substituents (methyl, methoxy, chloro and nitro) in the aromatic ring of benzylalcohol to probe electronic effects displayed no regular trends in the conversion. The catalytic oxidation of alcohols in the given conditions showed excellent efficiency in terms of yield and selectivity (100%).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0390" view="all">Also various types of structurally diverse substrates underwent smooth and selective oxidation to produce the corresponding sulfoxides in good yields. In order to compare catalytic reactivity of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> with other Mn(II) complexes, we used the same optimization condition with our previous work . Aliphatic and aromatic sulfides were effectively oxidized to the corresponding sulfoxides with full selectivity and no over oxidation to sulfone were observed (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0030"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Also various types of structurally diverse substrates underwent smooth and selective oxidation to produce the corresponding sulfoxides in good yields. In order to compare catalytic reactivity of 5 and 6 with other Mn(II) complexes, we used the same optimization condition with our previous work . Aliphatic and aromatic sulfides were effectively oxidized to the corresponding sulfoxides with full selectivity and no over oxidation to sulfone were observed ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0395" view="all">Generally, the result of catalytic studies using these two catalysts reveals that the efficiency of catalysts <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> towards all the substrates is almost the same in term of conversion and selectivity. The complexes show prolific catalytic activity in the oxidation of various sulfides and alcohols.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Generally, the result of catalytic studies using these two catalysts reveals that the efficiency of catalysts 5 and 6 towards all the substrates is almost the same in term of conversion and selectivity. The complexes show prolific catalytic activity in the oxidation of various sulfides and alcohols.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0400" view="all">Several novel halide and pseudohalides manganese(II) complexes containing <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand have been synthesized and fully characterized. The studies have shown that the choice of manganese(II) salt is crucial in the formation of manganese(II) complexes with <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> and pseudohalide ligands. In the reported compounds the manganese(II) ions show various coordination geometries but <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic> ligand coordinates to metal center in the most common tridentate coordination mode. Manganese(II) ions of 1D chain network [Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(dca)(tppz)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> are linked by a single <ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic> dicyanamido group, whereas the metal center of dimers [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-Cl)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-κN1)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] are bridged by chloride and azide ions, respectively. Future studies will be focused on design of <ce:italic>tppz</ce:italic>-bridged manganese(II) complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Several novel halide and pseudohalides manganese(II) complexes containing tppz ligand have been synthesized and fully characterized. The studies have shown that the choice of manganese(II) salt is crucial in the formation of manganese(II) complexes with tppz and pseudohalide ligands. In the reported compounds the manganese(II) ions show various coordination geometries but tppz ligand coordinates to metal center in the most common tridentate coordination mode. Manganese(II) ions of 1D chain network [Mn(NO3)(dca)(tppz)] n  are linked by a single end-to-end dicyanamido group, whereas the metal center of dimers [Mn2(μ-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2] and [Mn2Cl2(μ-N3-κN1)2(tppz)2] are bridged by chloride and azide ions, respectively. Future studies will be focused on design of tppz-bridged manganese(II) complexes.

(1) [Mn2(μ-Cl)2Cl2(tppz)2]

The compound was prepared by employing MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.2g, 1mmol) and tppz (0.39g, 1mmol). Yield 75% (390mg).

Calc. for C48H32Cl4Mn2N12: C, 56.05; H, 3.14; N, 16.34. Found: C, 56.34; H, 3.08; N, 16.52%.

IR (KBr, cm-1): 1631 (w), 1594 (s), 1567 (sh) and 1536 (w) ν(CN) and ν(CC).

(5) [Mn(NO3)2(tppz)(H2O)]

The compound was prepared by employing Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.2g, 0.8mmol) and tppz (0.31g, 0.8mmol). Yield 70% (327mg).

Calc. for C24H18MnN8O7: C, 49.24; H, 3.10; N, 9.38. Found: C, 49.96; H, 3.21; N, 9.81%.

IR (KBr, cm-1): 3415 (br) ν(OH) 1666 (w), 1639 (w), 1590 (m) and 1574 (sh) ν(CN) and ν(CC).

Preparation of [Mn2Cl2(μ-N3-kN1)2(tppz)2] (2), [MnCl(SCN)(tppz)(H2O)]⋅H2O (3) [MnCl(dca)(tppz)(H2O)0.57(MeOH)0.47] (4), [Mn(N3)(NO3)(tppz)(H2O)] (6), [Mn(SCN)2(tppz)] (7) and [Mn(NO3)(dca)(tppz)] n  (8)

cln_elements.clean_text:
Studies on tppz metal(II) complexes have illustrated the ability of this polydentate organic ligand to mediate magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers bridged by the central pyrazine moiety and hence separated by more than 6.4Å . The largest antiferromagnetic interaction has been found in the dinuclear complexes [Cu2(tppz)(H2O)4](ClO4)4⋅2H2O (J =-61.1cm-1) and [Ni2(tppz)(H2O)6](NO3)4⋅2.5H2O (J =-76cm-1) . Interestingly, the relatively good efficiency of the tppz bridge in transmitting magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers contrasts with much poorer ability of unsubstituted pyrazine bridges in its metal complexes, where negligible or weak antiferromagnetic interactions were observed (with J values ranging from -0.14cm-1 in [Ni(pyz)2Cl2] to 15.1cm-1 in Cu(pyz)2(ReO4)2) . In binuclear ruthenium(II) complexes, tppz bridges have been found to mediate intermetallic electronic communication through the π symmetry orbitals . In turn, the mononuclear complexes of Co(II) of formula [Co(tppz)2]2+ with tppz ligands coordinated in a tridentate coordination mode attract scientific interest due to thermally induced spin crossover behaviour from a high-spin S Co =3/2 at high temperatures to a low-spin S Co =1/2 at lower temperatures .

Magnetic measurement and EPR spectra

Variable-temperature magnetic measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMSXL-5-type) at a magnetic field of 0.5T over the temperature range 1.8-300K. Correction are based on subtracting the sample-holder signal, contribution χ Dia estimated from Pascal constants . The effective magnetic moment was calculated from the equation:     μ   eff   = 2.83 (   χ   M   T   )   1 / 2     (B.M.). Magnetization versus magnetic field measurements were carried out at 2K in the magnetic field range 0-5T.

Magnetic properties and EPR spectra

The values χMT of monometallic complexes in the temperature range 10-300K are near constant. The slight decrease of the value χMT at the lowest temperatures range (1.8-10K) is caused by occurrence of a very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) centers in the crystal lattice. All magnetic data are presented in  .

The variation of the magnetization M versus the magnetic field H have been measured for all complexes at 2K indicates linear relation to ~1T and than continues Brillouin function. All these data confirms presence of spin S = 5/2 and a small lowering values of magnetic moment of manganese(II) centers. The EPR parameters of powdered spectra of all compounds are presented in the .

The least-squares fit of the experimental data using this equation was limited to the whole temperature range from 1.8K up to 300K and leads to J =-0.1cm-1, zJ' =-0.0cm-1 and g =1.97 with the agreement factor R equal 6.9×10-5 for complex 8. Experimental magnetic data plotted as χMT versus T for 1D chain complex are shown in .

Weak ferromagnetic behaviours of dinuclear compounds are evident from the magnetic measurements. The χMT value increases only at the lowest temperature, reaching maximums at 3.3K and 16K and than decreases on cooling down to 1.8K. for 1 and 2 compound, adequate.

Table 5. Oxidation of alcohols by the catalyst Oxone/n-Bu4NBr catalytic system[^a]

| Entry | Substrate | Product | GC yield% | GC yield% |
|-------|-----------|---------|-----------|-----------|
|       | Compound 5|         | 100       | 100       |
|       | Compound 6|         | 100       | 100       |
| 1     | ![fx2][]  | ![fx3][]| 100       | 100       |
| 2     | ![fx4][]  | ![fx5][]| 100       | 100       |
| 3     | ![fx6][]  | ![fx7][]| 100       | 100       |
| 4     | ![fx8][]  | ![fx9][]| 100       | 100       |
| 5     | ![fx10][] | ![fx11][]| 100      | 100       |
| 6     | ![fx12][] | ![fx13][]| 92        | 93        |
| 7     | ![fx14][] | ![fx15][]| 93        | 93        |
| 8     | ![fx16][] | ![fx17][]| 94        | 91        |

[^a]: The molar ratios for catalyst:phase transfer agent:substrate:oxidant are 1:10:20:20, respectively. The reactions were run for 5min at room temperature in a biphasic medium (CH2Cl2/H2O).
